title: The geometry of cortical representations of touch in rodents - Nature Neuroscience

last_post.content:
#NeuroPaperThread #NeuroNewPaper

1) Our article “The geometry of cortical representations of touch in rodents” with @chrisXrodgers Randy Bruno and @StefanoFusi is finally out! In brief, we found that whisker contacts in mice S1 are represented in approximately orthogonal subspaces https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-022-01237-9 🧵​👇​

Because of reasons (see https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.3000356 ) we decided to try to disassemble the communities —i.e. isolate each member species from a community and then rebuild the community with fixed initial population sizes— between rounds of selection.

This allows us to change the species composition and explore the landscape of different communities. As an effect, we can find communities that degrade better than the initial ones, i.e. we can actually IMPROVE the max function.

@aparrish We see related problems in clinical #neurology, where our diagnostic criteria for aphasia assume English structure. E.g., one diagnostic criterion for semantic dementia is "surface dysgraphia"--improper regularization, like writing "yacht" as "yot." But this criterion relies on English's orthographic opacity, and wouldn't appear in languages like Spanish, Korean or Russian with more regular orthography.

Here's a fascinating paper by my colleague Boon Lead Tee on dysgraphia in Chinese-speakers with primary progressive aphasia: https://doi.org/10.1212/wnl.0000000000200350. Because Chinese writing is so different from English, these disorders manifest in really interestingly different ways--some analogous to presentations in English, others entirely distinct. Anyway, a challenge for cross-cultural diagnosis and management...

@michael_nielsen Btw, I consider any type of axiomatic characterization in mathematics as a form of discovery fiction.

For example, Shannon entropy was characterized by Faddeev as the only continuous function from probability distributions to real numbers that satisfies a very natural chain rule.

This is a simple way to motivate the entropy. The well-known formula with a logarithm then pops out of it by itself.

I first learned about this from a nice paper by Leinster:

@michael_nielsen This paper by @johncarlosbaez, Fritz and Leinster is also effectively discovery fiction:
http://arxiv.org/abs/1106.1791

They consider a natural notion of information loss of a measure-preserving function, which has a simple and linear-looking definition. However, it turns out to coincide with the difference of entropies!

I find this much more satisfying that simply accepting the definition of entropy or trying to explain Shannon's source coding theorem to motivate it.

title: Higher categorical symmetries and gauging in two-dimensional spin systems

last_post.content:
The most exciting thing I ever realized was that physics in n dimensions is governed by n-categories.

The reason is that you can use an n-category to describe what happens when you glue together chunks of n-dimensional space, or spacetime.

I got this idea around 1994 thanks to the work of Louis Crane and conversations with James Dolan. It's taking a long time for people to work out the consequences, but it really warms my heart to see progress like this:

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01259

(1/n)

The Messier 106 Galaxy

This galaxy harbors a peculiar system in its nuclear region: a water vapor megamaser, the equivalent of a laser operating in microwave instead of visible light and on a galactic scale!

This maser plays an important role in the calibration of the cosmic distance ladder. Six such galactic maser systems are exploited in our recently published Cosmicflows-4 catalog of galaxy distances: https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.11238

title: Why high-profile journals have more retractions - Nature

last_post.content: (Singling out CNS as these are the "high prestige" journals, even if it has been shown before that they actually have a higher retraction rate https://www.nature.com/articles/nature.2014.15951)

This post on not sending people to mars https://idlewords.com/2023/1/why_not_mars.htm reminded me that there's this trail of CNS papers that the community decided are BS, but still linger without any notice or retraction. Like this one on a 250 million year old, viable bacterium https://www.nature.com/articles/35038060 or DNA from dinosaur bones https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.7973705 . There's a refuting technical comment on the latter (https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.7761839), but it's not mentioned or linked from the original paper
